TextView.android:text: What is an interval?

An interval is a relationship between two musical notes. Two notes can be identical, close together, or far apart. Some intervals are consonant (generally perceived as more pleasing to the ear) and some are dissonant (less pleasing to the ear).\n\nIt's important to remember that an interval is the relationship between two notes and not dependent on the notes themselves. You will find below examples of intervals being played at low, medium, and high pitches.
Listening for Intervals

In Earful's Musician Mode, you will listen to two notes played one after the other and then be asked to identify the relationship between them. Higher levels will unlock more intervals to practice, and the intervals at higher levels become increasingly difficult.
Perfect 1
A perfect 1 (commonly known as unison) is the simplest interval. Both notes played in a perfect 1 are identical.
Minor 2

A minor 2 consists of two notes that are one half-step apart. On a piano, this would be represented as two notes that are right next to each other. This interval is commonly recognized as interval in the Jaws theme.
Major 2

A major 2 is one half-step up from a minor 2. On a piano, this would be represented as two white keys with a black key in between. This interval is commonly recognized as the notes Do and Re in Do-Re-Mi from the Sound of Music, or the first two different notes in Happy Birthday ("Happy" and "birth").
Minor 3

A minor 3 is one half-step above a major 2 and is also known as an augmented 2. This interval is commonly recognized in Michael Jackson's "Bad" ("I'm" and "bad") or the first two notes of Brahms's "Lullaby".
Major 3
A major 3 is a half-step above a minor 3. This interval is commonly recognized as the first two notes of "Oh When the Saints" or The Beatles's "Can't Buy Me Love" ("can't" and "buy").
Perfect 4

A perfect 4 is a half-step above a major 3. It is commonly recognized as the first two notes of "Here Comes the Bride," the first two notes of "Amazing Grace," or the first two notes of the Harry Potter theme.
Minor 5

A minor 5 is a half-step above a perfect 4 and is also known as an augmented 4 or, more commonly, a tritone. This interval is commonly recognized as the first two notes in The Simpson's theme or "Maria" from West Side Story ("Ma" and "ri" of "Ma-ri-a").
Perfect 5
A perfect 5 is a half-step above a tritone. This interval is commonly recognized as the first two notes of the Star Wars theme or "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star."
Minor 6
A minor 6 is a half-step above a perfect 5. This interval is commonly recognized as the first two notes of Scott Joplin's "The Entertainer."
Major 6
A major 6 is a half-step above a minor 6. It is commonly recognized as the first two notes of the NBC chime or the first two notes of "Jingle Bells" ("Dash-ing").
Minor 7

A minor 7 is a half-step above a major 6 and is also known as an augmented 6. This interval is commonly recognized as the first two notes of the chorus of "The Winner Takes It All" by ABBA ("The win-" and "-ner").
Major 7
A major 7 is a half-step above a minor 7. It is commonly recognized as the first two notes of the Superman theme or the first two notes of the chorus of "Take On Me" by A-Ha ("Take" and "on").
Perfect 8

A perfect 8, more commonly known as an octave, is a half-step higher than a major 7. Two notes that are an octave apart have the same name. For example, in the sample sound, both notes played are a C, but in different octaves. An octave is commonly recognized as the first two notes of "Somewhere Over the Rainbow."
Receiving Points

When practicing in Musician Mode, you may choose a level to practice on. The level determines which intervals will be included in the exercise. Practicing earns you points, which unlock higher levels. Points will be awarded once an exercise (10 questions) is complete.

The level number will determine how many points you earn per question. For example, Level 1 awards one point per correct answer, Level 2 awards two points per correct answer, and so on.

To reach each level, you must accumulate the following number of points:

Level 2: 100 points

Level 3: 300 points

Level 4: 600 points

Level 5: 1000 points
